CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalisation that if CLINTON's emphasis on cooperation with Muslim nations and the American Muslim community leads to increased intelligence benefits?
Is CLINTONâ€™s assertion that Donald has been very dismissive of working with NATO and Muslim nations consistent with what other experts say about Trump's foreign policy approach?

Are there differences between the approach of the Clinton administration and the Trump administration in dealing with Muslim nations and communities that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited, where the Clinton administration emphasizes cooperation and the Trump administration is characterized by alienation?

Is it practically possible for the US to effectively combat terrorism and gather intelligence from European and Middle Eastern allies if they are alienated and pushed away by Donald's rhetoric, which has been consistently dismissive of Muslim nations and communities?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of 'having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes' that may undermine the effectiveness of this plan, such as the influence of special interest groups or the complexity of the tax system?
Is CLINTON's claim that the wealthy should pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes consistent with what other experts in the domain of economic policy say?

Are there differences between Clinton's proposals and the policies of other developed countries that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited, where the wealthy are also made to pay their fair share and corporate loopholes are closed?
Is it practically possible for the wealthy to pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes without significantly increasing taxes on the middle class?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalisation that if a country prioritizes clean energy then it will become the clean-energy superpower of the 21st century?
Is what CLINTON said about climate change being real consistent with what other experts in the field of climate science say?
Are five million people losing their homes similar in the respect cited to the loss of nine million jobs?
Is it true that the policies that failed in the past, such as those proposed by Donald, are indeed the reason for the economic recovery mentioned by Clinton, rather than his own proposals?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of NATO invoking Article 5 in response to the threat from Iran?
Is what CLINTON said clear? Are there technical terms used that are not explained clearly, such as "Article 5" and "nuclear fuel cycle" and "centrifuges" that are not explained clearly?

Are there differences between NATO's response to the 9/11 attacks and Iran's nuclear program that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited, where NATO invoked Article 5 in response to the 9/11 attacks but the international community did not invoke a similar collective response to Iran's nuclear program?

Is it practically possible for NATO invoking Article 5 in response to a hypothetical threat from Iran to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear bomb, given that NATO only invoked Article 5 once before in response to 9/11 and the circumstances were different?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of 'Iran not having nuclear capabilities' aside from the sanctions and diplomatic efforts, considering the fact that the US had a different president in the office after Clinton?

Is CLINTON's claim that she "driv[ed] them to the negotiating table" consistent with the fact that the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), which was signed in 2015, was a product of a diplomatic effort led by the Obama administration, and that the US Congress had already imposed economic sanctions on Iran through the Iran Sanctions Act of 2010, with CLINTON as a senator at that time?

Are the sanctions imposed on Iran by President Clinton and those imposed by President Obama under similar circumstances similar in the respect cited by Clinton, where he claims that the latter was effective without firing a single shot, while the former was not?
Is it practically possible for the sanctions imposed by Clinton to have driven Iran to the negotiating table without the involvement of Russia and China?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalisation that if a leader has a perceived lack of temperance, then they are not fit to hold the office of commander-in-chief?
Is CLINTON's assertion that CLINTON is not the right temperament to be commander-in-chief consistent with what other experts in the domain of US Presidential Leadership say?
Are there differences between the temperaments of other past presidents and Donald Trump that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited between their temperaments and Trump's?
Is being taunted by the public a bad characteristic for a commander-in-chief to have?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalisation that if a leader's cavalier attitude towards nuclear weapons becomes a prominent concern, then the threat of nuclear weapons being used by terrorists becomes a major issue?

Is CLINTON's assertion that a cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is the number-one threat we face in the world consistent with what other experts in the field of international security and nuclear policy say?

Are there differences between the threat of nuclear weapons falling into the hands of terrorists and other threats (such as chemical or biological weapons) that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited?
Is his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalization that if Clinton described the problem as "good" then the issue is significant?

Is CLINTON a genuine expert in the domain of describing problems, and did he really assert that "It's a good one, though" is a good description of the problem? If not, is a reference to the original source given? Can it be checked?
Is the description given by Clinton of the problem similar to the description of the Watergate scandal?
Is it practically possible for Clinton's statement to prevent the problem it describes?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of 'being able to rely on US leadership and decisions that further peace and prosperity'?
Is what CLINTON said clear? Are there technical terms used that are not explained clearly?

Are there differences between Clinton's approach to dealing with ISIS and the way he criticizes his opponent's deal with Iran that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited between his approach and his criticism?
Is his alternative plan to defeat ISIS a secret plan because it is not effective or because he genuinely believes it's a matter of national security?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalisation that if deploying a half a billion more solar panels then we can build a new modern electric grid?
Is CLINTON's assertion that we can deploy a half a billion more solar panels consistent with what other experts in the domain of energy policy say?

Are there differences between the economic plans proposed by Clinton and those implemented in countries like Germany or Sweden that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited between their approach to dealing with climate issues and economic growth?
Is it practically possible for deploying a half a billion more solar panels to happen in the given time frame and resources without significant investments and technological advancements?
